channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

ã€

#â€‹546 â€” March 19, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Traversal-Resistant File APIs â€” Among the lesser known new features in recent versions of Go are some ways to improve file system security when end user input might have an impact on file paths your app tries to access, including os.Root, filepath.IsLocal, filepath.EvalSymLinks and filepath.Localize. A mustÂ read.

Damien Neil

Were Multiple Return Values a Mistake for Go? â€” An interesting technical post critiquing the effects of one of Goâ€™s earliest design decisions. This is an area where opinions will differ strongly, but the author thinks Go sorely needs to supportÂ tuples.

Mond

ğŸ“… Live Workshop: Build Production-Ready Apps with JavaScript & Go â€” Join Maximiliano Firtman next week (online or in-person) for a 3-day workshop, learning how to build real-world, fully functional web apps using vanilla JS & Go. Create performant, scalableÂ apps.

Frontend Masters sponsor

TypeScript's Go Port Already Leading to Optimizations for Go â€” Last weekâ€™s big news was about the TypeScript compiler being ported to Go for performance reasons. A neat side effect of such a large project entering our ecosystem is the increased potential for even more performance improvements for GoÂ itself, something that has already begun toÂ occur..

GitHub Go Repo

Go Structs and Interfaces Made Simple â€” An introduction (or refresher) of Goâ€™s core building blocks when it comes to working with data types and structs â€“ an approach that differs somewhat from those favored in object oriented languages like C++ orÂ Java.

Deven J (Stream)

ğŸ“„ Benchmarking: What You Can't Miss in Go 1.24 Jakub Jarosz

ğŸ“„ How GitHub Engineers Learn New Codebases Brittany Ellich (GitHub)

ğŸ“º How to Implement Server-Sent Events in Go Alex Pliutau

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

doomgeneric: Doom, Ported to Go? â€” If classic 90s FPS Doom can be ported to JavaScript and made to run inside a PDF, a Go port should be a piece of cake, right? Hereâ€™s a little slice of magic involving using the ccgo C-to-GoÂ compiler. Don't get too excited though as it's a limited proof of concept and Linux only, but it's neat to see what ccgo is capableÂ of.

cznic

golang-set: A Simple, Well-Tested, Generic Set Type â€” â€œUntil Go has sets built-inâ€¦use this.â€ The latest v2.8 release adds support for Go 1.23â€™s range-over-funcÂ iteration.

Ralph Caraveo

ğŸ”’ Protect Against AI Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time â€” WorkOS Radar protects your app with advanced device fingerprinting â€” stop fake signups, free tier abuse, bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

WorkOS sponsor

DiceDB: A Reactive, In-Memory Database Optimized for ModernÂ Hardware â€” A new Go-powered database! Dice is a reactive database where your clients subscribe to receive changes immediately and it seems to take a lot of inspiration from the Redis approach being both in-memory and with simple Redis-like commands. GitHubÂ repo.

DiceDB

Participle: A Simple Library for Defining Parsers â€” Provides a straightforward yet idiomatic way to define parsers in Go using a familiar approach of using struct field tags to define a grammar, so if youâ€™ve used encoding/json before, youâ€™re well on yourÂ way.

Alec Thomas

  • Glamour 0.9 â€“ Stylesheet-based Markdown rendering for CLI apps, now with better syntax highlight andÂ tables.

  • Toxiproxy 2.12 â€“ Simulate 'chaotic' network conditions in both testing and developmentÂ environments.

  • ğŸ Viper 1.20 â€“ Config solution for Go apps supporting various file formats and environmentÂ variables.

  • ğŸ“° Fusion 0.9 â€“ Lightweight, self-contained feed aggregator and reader. Built with Go, SQLite, andÂ Svelte.

  • go-github v70.0.0 â€“ Go client library for accessing the GitHub API v3.

  • River v0.19 â€“ Robust job processing system for Go and Postgres.

  • GoReleaser v2.8 â€“ Mostly improvements to the Pro version.

  • TOML 1.5 â€“ TOML config file parser forÂ Go.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€How Swiss Tables make Go 1.24 fasterã€‘ç‘å£«æ¡Œå­å¦‚ä½•æ›´å¿«åœ°1.24
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹544 â€” March 5, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Faster Go Maps with Swiss Tables â€” One of Goâ€™s newest features is a revamped map implementation powered by a new hash table algorithm called Swiss Table that boosts map operations up to 60% faster in microbenchmarks, while reducing memory overhead. Hereâ€™s a look at how itÂ works.

Michael Pratt

Tips to Debug Hanging Go Programs â€” Next time your Go app becomes unresponsive, these tips can help you find the issue by forcing a stack trace or using Delve to attach to the process (or core dump) and revive theÂ program.

Michael Stapelberg

Keep Postgres Maintenance from Slowing Down Your Go App â€” Secure your spot to learn the proactive maintenance practices that uncover hidden database performance risks, like slow queries, checkpoint behavior, & connection issues, before theyÂ escalate.

pganalyze sponsor

The Cost of Go's panic and recover â€” When something goes unexpectedly and critically wrong in a Go program you might use panic to abort things quickly, but did you know you can use recover to manage what happens after a panic? This means you could use it as a sort of control flow mechanism, if you were in a particularly unorthodoxÂ mood..

Julien Cretel

ğŸ’¡ This post led to a rather extensive discussion on Hacker News.

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ GopherConUK returns to London this August and its call for papers has just opened if you'd like to speak. You can submit a talk up until MayÂ 17.

  • go-attention is an attempt to create a pure Go implementation of attention mechanisms and transformer layers, such as used in modernÂ LLMs.

Calling Rust from 'Cursed' Go â€” Cgo is Goâ€™s mechanism for calling external/foreign functions but its performance often causes consternation. Enter purego, a still-in-beta way to make such calls without Cgo.

Preston Thorpe

Nil Channels in Go â€” Nil channels seem to baffle many Gophers, so Vishnu went on a quest to figure out why in a particular case. This led him to the wisdom of a new Go proverb: â€œInit when you split; Nil when youÂ merge.â€

Vishnu Bharathi

The Magic of Small Engineering Teams â€” How PostHog uses small teams to ship fast and scale at the sameÂ time.

PostHog sponsor

ğŸ“„ Minesweeper with Raylib Go Bindings â€“ Alex reflects on the joys of basic game development in Go with Raylib and he shares his codeÂ too. Alex Pliutau

ğŸ“„ We Switched from Java to Go and Don't Regret It Miglinci, Steiner, and Enne (Glasskube)

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Gore 0.6: A Full Featured Go REPL Environment â€” You get all the niceties youâ€™d expect like line editing, history, multi-line input, the ability to import packages, and, in this latest build, gopls-powered code completionÂ too.

motemen

Go Clean Template â€” Inspired by Uncle Bobâ€™s â€˜Clean Codeâ€™ principles, this repo attempts to provide a â€˜clean architecture templateâ€™ for building Go-powered services that are well organized and wonâ€™t turn into a mess. You be theÂ judge.

Evrone

go-git 5.14: An Extensible Git Implementation in Pure Go â€” â€œManipulate git repositories at low level (plumbing) or high level (porcelain), through an idiomatic Go API.â€ Now requires GoÂ 1.23+.

go-git

sqldef 1.0: Idempotent Schema Management for Databases â€” A Go-powered CLI tool and WASM library for diffing SQL schemas (demo here). Supports MySQL, Postgres, SQLite and SQL Server. Built by one of Rubyâ€™s core teamÂ members,Â too.

Takashi Kokubun

  • â­ TinyGo 0.36.0 â€“ The much celebrated Go compiler 'for small places' gains Go 1.24 and LLVM 19 support, as well as support for several newÂ boards.

  • MongoDB Go Driver v2.1 â€“ Officially supported driver to work with MongoDB. Now supporting MongoDB's new bulk write API and BSON vectorÂ datatype.

  • gocron v2.16.0 â€“ Job scheduling package for running Go functions at specifiedÂ intervals.

  • Wait4X 3.0 â€“ CLI tool for waiting on various ports or services to reach a specifiedÂ state.

  • pgroll v0.10 â€“ Tool for zero-downtime, reversible schema PostgresÂ migrations.

  • Glow 2.1 â€“ Terminal-based Markdown rendering from the folks atÂ Charm.

  • Pion WebRTC 4.0.13 â€“ Pure Go implementation of the WebRTCÂ API.

  • Sarama v1.45.1 â€“ IBM's Go client library for ApacheÂ Kafka.

  • Hugo v0.145.0

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ“Œ Faster Deployment â€“ Integrate CarsXEâ€™s API in minutes and get real-time vehicle data with ease. Try it now!Â 

Blacksmith runs GitHub Actions 2x faster at half the cost with a one-line code change. Trusted by 250+ companies like Ashby andÂ Clerk.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in dev

A quick roundup of some of other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • ğŸ¤¯ Someone managed to implement 90s FPS game Doom entirely in the TypeScript type system.

  • And if you've never quite grokked how TypeScript ticks, Dr. Axel Rauschmayer has a succinct explanation of how it differs from JavaScript in a practical day-to-day tooling sense.

  • ğŸ¤– Microsoft and GitHub are getting into the 'AI developer agents' game and have showed off a look at GitHub Copilot 'agent mode' running in VSÂ Code.

  • Is it possible to think about game 'speedrunning' as essentially a form of vulnerability research?

ã€‘

Motemen

item.title: ã€Cleanups and weak pointers in Go 1.24ã€‘æ¸…ç†å’Œè™šå¼±çš„æŒ‡é’ˆ1.24
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹545 â€” March 12, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

TypeScript's Compiler to Get 10x Faster, Thanks to Go â€” TypeScript has shaken up the JavaScript ecosystem in recent years with an increasing number of developers relying on its strong typing and added structure. TypeScriptâ€™s compiler isnâ€™t particularly fast, though, but the TypeScript team at Microsoft is changing that by porting it toÂ Go!

Anders Hejlsberg (Microsoft)

ğŸ“º The Syntax podcast had Anders on for an episode discussing the whole porting process. Lots of details for those who want to goÂ deeper.

Why Reimplement TypeScript's Compiler in Go? â€” Many people have been asking why Microsoft is porting TypeScriptâ€™s compiler to Go rather than, say, Rust or C#. TypeScriptâ€™s architect Anders Hejlsberg delivered the definitive comment on the matter: Go fit the technical requirements and proved the best high performance language to which to port JavaScript for a variety ofÂ reasons.

Microsoft's TypeScript Repo

ğŸ”’ Protect Against AI Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time â€” With WorkOS Radar you can detect, verify and block harmful behaviour, protecting your app with advanced device fingerprinting. Stop fake signups, stop free tier abuse, and stop bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

Workos sponsor

New Low-Level Tools for Garbage Collection Efficiency â€” A look at two new features offered by Go 1.24â€™s garbage collector: runtime.AddCleanup and weak.Pointer. Cleanups are like finalizers, but get around some of their quirks by not resurrecting objects theyâ€™re attached to. Weak pointers, meanwhile, let you reference objects without preventing their garbageÂ collection.

Michael Knyszek

ğŸ’¡ The Go team has updated the Go garbage collector docs with info about the aboveÂ features.

Different Ways of Working with SQL Databases in Go â€” Starting with a simple schema presenting a basic blog system, Alex walks through a variety of approaches from working with raw SQL and database/sql to sqlx, using ORMs, and sqlc.

Alex Pliutau

Building a Secure Session Manager â€” The stateless nature of requests to a webapp demands some sort of session management, most commonly via a cookie containing a unique ID to identify the user. Mohamed looks at a way to keep this whole processÂ secure.

Mohamed Said

ğŸ’¡ Mohamed follows on with Implementing Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection in Go WebÂ Apps.

Using Cursor for Large Projects â€” If youâ€™ve tried using tools like Cursor to write Go code in larger projects, youâ€™ll have almost certainly run into its limitations. Thierry has some tips for adding a bit of structure to the ghost in theÂ machine.

Thierry S. (Stream)

Sign Up for a Workshop to Get Started Building Go-Powered Decentralized Apps â€” App builders, Go enthusiasts, tinkerers: come and build on gnoâ€¤land, a smart contract platform for a freer, fairerÂ world.

gnoâ€¤land sponsor

ğŸ“„ Building Cross-Platform SDKs: From FFI to WebAssembly â€“ Another story where Cgo reared its ugly head and forced a differentÂ approach. Mark Phelps (Flipt)

ğŸ“„ The Benefits of Native FIPS Support in Go 1.24 Derek Parker (Red Hat)

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

RobotGo: Native Cross-Platform GUI Automation â€” A way to control the pointer, keyboard, read the screen, etc. Combine this with an LLM perhaps.. if youÂ dare?

V Caesar et al.

ghw 0.15.0: A Go Hardware Discovery/Inspection Library â€” Find out things about the memory, CPU, storage, network support, and similar things about the host computer. Focused on Linux and Windows, with partial macOSÂ support.

Jay Pipes

ObjectBox Go 1.9: A Fast, Embedded Database for Go Objects â€” Store objects in ObjectBox and find them again using powerfulÂ queries.

ObjectBox Ltd.

  • ğŸ¤– Ollama v0.6 â€“ Tool for running and managing large language models. v0.6 adds support for Google's new Gemma 3 model.

  • Gum v0.16 â€“ Tool for creating stylish shell scripts with customizable utilities.

  • Semantic Search 0.4 â€“ Library for embedded vector searching and semantic embedding generation withÂ llama.cpp.

  • Ark 0.3 â€“ Entity Component System (ECS) forÂ Go.

  • Microsoft's Builds of Go 1.24.1-1 and 1.23.7-1

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Infrastructure Identity: A New Paradigm for Trustworthy Computing in a Zero Trust World â€“ Download your copyÂ here.

ğŸ‘€ Give your eyes a break! MonoLisa makes coding more comfortable. Try MonoLisaÂ now.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in dev

A quick roundup of some other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • The HTTP Archive has finished publishing their Web Almanac for 2024, a fantastic resource of information about how technologies are really used on the modern Web in areas as diverse as HTTP support, security, andÂ JavaScript.

  • A developer is facing potential jail time for deploying a 'kill switch' into his employer's systems to perform nefarious actions if he were to be removed from the company's staff directory.

  • ğŸ˜ If you've got Postgres SQL query plans you need to analyze, these are some of the tools to try.

  • ğŸ¤– Esteemed LLM-whisperer Simon Willison drops a ton of insights and tips on how he uses LLMs to help him write code.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

delivered the definitive comment on the matter: Go fit the technical requirements and proved the best high performance language to which to port JavaScript for a variety ofÂ reasons.

Microsoftçš„æ‰“å­—ç¨¿repo

- å¦‚æœæ‚¨å°è¯•ä½¿ç”¨å…‰æ ‡ç­‰å·¥å…·åœ¨è¾ƒå¤§çš„é¡¹ç›®ä¸­ç¼–å†™GOä»£ç ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå‡ ä¹å¯ä»¥è‚¯å®šä¼šé‡åˆ°å…¶é™åˆ¶ã€‚è’‚åŸƒé‡Œï¼ˆThierryï¼‰æœ‰ä¸€äº›æŠ€å·§ï¼Œå¯ä»¥åœ¨æœºå™¨ä¸­çš„å¹½çµä¸­æ·»åŠ ä¸€äº›ç»“æ„ã€‚

Thierry S.ï¼ˆæµï¼‰

gnoã€‚

item.title: ã€gopls can now suggest ways to modernize your Go codeã€‘GOPLç°åœ¨å¯ä»¥å»ºè®®æ‚¨ç°ä»£åŒ–GOä»£ç çš„æ–¹æ³•
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹543 â€” February 26, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Testing Concurrent Code with testing/synctest â€” Concurrency is one of Goâ€™s natural strengths, but testing heavily concurrent programs can be tricky. Go 1.24 introduces a new (though experimental and hidden behind an environment variable) package for testing code involving time or concurrency. The Go team wants you to have a play and send in yourÂ feedback.

Damien Neil

Prepare Your App for AI Agents â€” Stytch extends auth to handle permissions for AI agentsâ€”so your app can securely delegate access to agents or protect against agent-powered threats. Check out our GoÂ quickstart.

Stytch sponsor

Extensible Wasm Applications with Go â€” â€œâ€¦ the ability to build a WASI reactor and export Go functions to Wasm in Go 1.24 represent a significant step forward for Goâ€™s WebAssembly capabilities. These features empower developers to create more versatile and powerful Go-based Wasm applications â€¦â€

Cherry Mui

IN BRIEF:

  • Go's LSP server (gopls) has a new version out that adds a modernize analyzer that can suggest ways your Go code could be updated to take advantage of new language features and standard libraryÂ APIs.

  • Ben Boyter's Searchcode code search engine is a fantastic project and it's now powered entirely by Go and an epic 6 terabyte SQLite file.

  • Former core team member Brad Fitzpatrick ran into a memory leak with unique.Handle and has written up his findings.

  • ğŸ“º Go had its own track at the recent FOSDEM conference and you can enjoy videos of most of the talks here. ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in dev

A quick roundup of some of other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • Anthropic released Claude 3.7, a new version of its popular large language model, and reports and benchmarks so far show it's really good for coding.

  • An interesting look at how Git's core contributors configure their own gitÂ setups.

  • Browser developers collaborate via a project called Interop and focus on features to bring to the Web platform each year. Interop 2025's priorities include the Storage Access API, CSS improvements, WebAssembly enhancements, andÂ more.

  • The XOR operator, and logic gate, explained. (You can use bitwise XOR yourself in Go with the ^ operator.)
